Data Module

This module provides classes for handling time series data.

TimeSeries

class finpie.data.timeseries.TimeSeries(data, metadata=None)[source]

Bases: object

Base class for time series data.

This class provides core functionality for handling time series data, including basic operations like resampling, returns calculation, and statistical measures.

__init__(data, metadata=None)[source]

Initialize a TimeSeries object.

Parameters:

  • data (DataFrame) – DataFrame with datetime index and price columns

  • metadata (TimeSeriesMetadata) – TimeSeriesMetadata object containing series information

property start_date: datetime

Get the start date of the time series.

property end_date: datetime

Get the end date of the time series.

property frequency: str

Get the frequency of the time series.

resample(freq)[source]

Resample the time series to a different frequency.

Parameters:

freq (str) – Target frequency (e.g., ‘1D’ for daily, ‘1H’ for hourly)

Return type:

TimeSeries

Returns:

New TimeSeries object with resampled data

returns(intraday_only=False, method='simple')[source]

Calculate returns for the time series.

Parameters:

  • intraday_only (bool) – Whether to drop the first record of each day

  • method (str) – Return calculation method (‘log’ or ‘simple’)

Return type:

TimeSeries

Returns:

TimeSeries object with returns data

rolling(window, stats=['mean', 'std', 'min', 'max'], min_periods=None)[source]

Calculate rolling statistics for the time series.

Parameters:

  • window (int) – Size of the rolling window

  • stats (List[str]) – List of statistics to calculate available stats: [‘mean’, ‘std’, ‘min’, ‘max’, ‘skew’, ‘kurt’, ‘sum’, ‘count’, ‘median’, ‘var’, ‘quantiles’]

  • min_periods (Optional[int]) – Minimum number of observations required

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

New TimeSeries object with rolling statistics

Convert the time series to a dictionary representation.

Returns:

Dictionary containing the time series data and metadata

MultiTimeSeries

class finpie.data.multitimeseries.MultiTimeSeries(timeseries)[source]

Bases: TimeSeries

A class for handling multiple time series together.

This class extends TimeSeries to provide functionality for analyzing multiple time series simultaneously. It supports operations like correlation analysis, portfolio construction, and risk metrics across multiple assets.

Variables:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – Combined DataFrame containing all time series data

  • timeseries (List[TimeSeries]) – List of individual TimeSeries objects

  • metadata (TimeSeriesMetadata) – Metadata for the combined time series

__init__(timeseries)[source]

Initialize a MultiTimeSeries object.

Parameters:

timeseries (Union[List[TimeSeries], List[DataFrame], List[Series], DataFrame]) – Can be one of: - List of TimeSeries objects - List of pandas DataFrames - List of pandas Series - Single DataFrame with multiple columns

Raises:

ValueError – If input is invalid or empty

_align_series()[source]

Align all time series to a common index.

Return type:

None

_create_metadata()[source]

Create metadata for the combined time series.

Return type:

TimeSeriesMetadata

correlation(returns=True, method='pearson', min_periods=None)[source]

Calculate correlation matrix between time series.

Parameters:

  • returns (bool) – Whether to use returns or original series. Defaults to True.

  • method (str) – Correlation method (‘pearson’, ‘kendall’, or ‘spearman’). Defaults to ‘pearson’.

  • min_periods (Optional[int]) – Minimum number of observations required. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Correlation matrix between all time series.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Note

If returns=True and the series is already returns, a warning will be logged.

rolling(window, stats=['mean', 'std', 'min', 'max', 'skew', 'kurt', 'sum', 'count', 'median', 'var', 'quantiles'], min_periods=None)[source]

Calculate rolling statistics for the time series.

Parameters:

  • window (int) – Size of the rolling window

  • stats (List[str]) – List of statistics to calculate available stats: [‘mean’, ‘std’, ‘min’, ‘max’, ‘skew’, ‘kurt’, ‘sum’, ‘count’, ‘median’, ‘var’, ‘quantiles’]

  • min_periods (Optional[int]) – Minimum number of observations required

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

DataFrame containing rolling statistics

covariance(returns=True, min_periods=None)[source]

Calculate covariance matrix between time series.

Parameters:

  • returns (bool) – Whether to use returns or original series. Defaults to True.

  • min_periods (Optional[int]) – Minimum number of observations required. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Covariance matrix between all time series.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Note

If returns=True and the series is already returns, a warning will be logged.

returns(intraday_only=False, method='simple')[source]

Calculate returns for all time series.

Parameters:

method (str) – Return calculation method (‘log’ or ‘simple’)

Return type:

MultiTimeSeries

Returns:

New MultiTimeSeries object with returns data

portfolio(weights, percentage=False, intraday_only=False, method='simple', shares=False)[source]

Calculate portfolio returns using given weights.

Parameters:

  • weights (Dict[str, float]) – Dictionary mapping symbols to weights

  • percentage (bool) – Whether to use percentage returns. Defaults to False.

  • intraday_only (bool) – Whether to use intraday only returns. Defaults to False.

  • method (str) – Return calculation method (‘log’ or ‘simple’). Defaults to ‘simple’.

  • shares (bool) – Whether to use weights as number of shares instead of percentage. Defaults to False.

Returns:

Portfolio returns time series.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Raises:

ValueError – If weights don’t sum to 1.0 (when shares=False) or if symbols are not found.

rolling_correlation(window, min_periods=None)[source]

Calculate rolling correlation matrices.

Parameters:

  • window (int) – Size of the rolling window

  • min_periods (Optional[int]) – Minimum number of observations required

Return type:

Dict[str, DataFrame]

Returns:

Dictionary mapping dates to correlation matrices

RatioTimeSeries

class finpie.data.ratiotimeseries.RatioTimeSeries(numerator, denominator)[source]

Bases: TimeSeries

A class for handling ratio-based time series.

This class extends TimeSeries to provide functionality for analyzing the ratio between two time series. It’s commonly used in pair trading and relative value strategies, where the relationship between two assets is analyzed through their price ratio.

Variables:

  • numerator (TimeSeries) – The numerator time series

  • denominator (TimeSeries) – The denominator time series

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – The ratio time series data

  • metadata (TimeSeriesMetadata) – Metadata for the ratio time series

__init__(numerator, denominator)[source]

Initialize a RatioTimeSeries object.

Parameters:

  • numerator (TimeSeries) – TimeSeries object for the numerator. Can also be a DataFrame or Series.

  • denominator (TimeSeries) – TimeSeries object for the denominator. Can also be a DataFrame or Series.

Note

If numerator or denominator are not TimeSeries objects, they will be converted automatically.

to_dict()[source]

Convert the RatioTimeSeries to a dictionary representation.

Returns:

Dictionary containing:

  • data: The ratio time series data

  • metadata: Metadata for the ratio time series

  • numerator: Dictionary representation of the numerator time series

  • denominator: Dictionary representation of the denominator time series

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

classmethod from_dict(data_dict)[source]

Create a RatioTimeSeries object from a dictionary representation.

Parameters:

data_dict (Dict[str, Any]) – Dictionary containing: - numerator: Dictionary representation of the numerator time series - denominator: Dictionary representation of the denominator time series

Returns:

New RatioTimeSeries object reconstructed from the dictionary

Return type:

RatioTimeSeries

__repr__()[source]

String representation of the RatioTimeSeries object.

Return type:

str

SpreadTimeSeries

class finpie.data.spreadtimeseries.SpreadTimeSeries(series1, series2, hedge_ratio=None)[source]

Bases: TimeSeries

A class for handling spread-based time series.

This class extends TimeSeries to provide functionality for analyzing the spread between two time series. It’s commonly used in spread trading and statistical arbitrage strategies, where the relationship between two assets is analyzed through their price spread, often with a hedge ratio.

Variables:

  • series1 (TimeSeries) – The first time series

  • series2 (TimeSeries) – The second time series

  • hedge_ratio (float) – The hedge ratio used to calculate the spread

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – The spread time series data

  • metadata (TimeSeriesMetadata) – Metadata for the spread time series

__init__(series1, series2, hedge_ratio=None)[source]

Initialize a SpreadTimeSeries object.

Parameters:

  • series1 (TimeSeries) – First TimeSeries object. Can also be a DataFrame or Series.

  • series2 (TimeSeries) – Second TimeSeries object. Can also be a DataFrame or Series.

  • hedge_ratio (Optional[float]) – Optional hedge ratio for series2. If None, will be calculated using OLS regression. Defaults to None.

Note

If series1 or series2 are not TimeSeries objects, they will be converted automatically. The hedge ratio is calculated using OLS regression if not provided.

_calculate_hedge_ratio(x, y)[source]

Calculate the hedge ratio using OLS regression.

Parameters:

  • x (pd.Series) – First time series

  • y (pd.Series) – Second time series

Returns:

Calculated hedge ratio using OLS regression

Return type:

float

Note

Both series must have the same index. The hedge ratio is calculated as the coefficient of the second series in the OLS regression of y on x.

get_hedge_ratio()[source]

Get the current hedge ratio.

Returns:

The hedge ratio used to calculate the spread

Return type:

float

to_dict()[source]

Convert the SpreadTimeSeries to a dictionary representation.

Returns:

Dictionary containing:

  • data: The spread time series data

  • metadata: Metadata for the spread time series

  • series1: Dictionary representation of the first time series

  • series2: Dictionary representation of the second time series

  • hedge_ratio: The hedge ratio used to calculate the spread

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

classmethod from_dict(data_dict)[source]

Create a SpreadTimeSeries object from a dictionary representation.

Parameters:

data_dict (Dict[str, Any]) – Dictionary containing: - series1: Dictionary representation of the first time series - series2: Dictionary representation of the second time series - hedge_ratio: The hedge ratio used to calculate the spread

Returns:

New SpreadTimeSeries object reconstructed from the dictionary

Return type:

SpreadTimeSeries

__repr__()[source]

String representation of the SpreadTimeSeries object.

Return type:

str
